deck.name: The NCO Guide
deck.description: TC 7-22.7 - NCO responsibilities, leadership, counseling, professional development, and training management

metadata.title: The Noncommissioned Officer Guide
metadata.proponent: United States Army Combined Arms Center

cards.front: What is the primary duty of an NCO?
cards.back:
To train Soldiers and lead them in the execution of tasks.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-2)

cards.front: What are the three main duties of every NCO?
cards.back:
Conduct training, Maintain and enforce standards, Take care of Soldiers.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-3)

cards.front: What are the three types of developmental counseling?
cards.back:
Event counseling, Performance counseling, and Professional growth counseling.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-4)

cards.front: When should performance counseling be conducted?
cards.back:
Within 30 days of initial assignment and quarterly thereafter.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-8)

cards.front: What form is used to document developmental counseling?
cards.back:
DA Form 4856 (Developmental Counseling Form).

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-12)

cards.front: What are the four stages of the counseling process?
cards.back:
Identify need, Prepare, Conduct, Follow up.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-15)

cards.front: What is event counseling?
cards.back:
Counseling that addresses specific events (positive or corrective) such as superior performance or misconduct.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-5)

cards.front: What is professional growth counseling?
cards.back:
Counseling focused on long-term career goals, professional development, and personal growth.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-7)

cards.front: What are the NCO's responsibilities regarding training?
cards.back:
Train Soldiers to standard, certify training proficiency, and maintain individual/crew readiness.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 2, para 2-4)

cards.front: What does 'train as you fight' mean?
cards.back:
Training should replicate combat conditions as closely as possible to prepare Soldiers for actual operations.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 2, para 2-8)

cards.front: What is the NCO Support Channel?
cards.back:
The communication path used by NCOs from squad leader through CSM parallel to the chain of command.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-8)

cards.front: What is the relationship between officers and NCOs?
cards.back:
Officers command, establish policy, and assign missions. NCOs train Soldiers, maintain standards, and execute missions.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-6)

cards.front: What are the three levels of leadership (BE, KNOW, DO)?
cards.back:
BE: Character and values. KNOW: Knowledge and skills. DO: Actions and influence.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-12)

cards.front: What is the purpose of the NCO Evaluation Report (NCOER)?
cards.back:
To evaluate NCO performance and potential, provide feedback, and inform personnel decisions.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 4, para 4-2)

cards.front: How often is an NCOER typically completed?
cards.back:
Annually, or upon change of rater, departure from unit, or completion of rating period.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 4, para 4-4)

cards.front: What form is used for the NCO Evaluation Report?
cards.back:
DA Form 2166-9 series (various versions for different ranks).

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 4, para 4-5)

cards.front: What is the NCO's role in maintaining discipline?
cards.back:
Enforce standards, correct deficiencies immediately, counsel Soldiers, and recommend appropriate action.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 2, para 2-15)

cards.front: What should an NCO do when a Soldier performs poorly?
cards.back:
Identify the cause, counsel the Soldier, develop a plan for improvement, and follow up.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-18)

cards.front: What is the purpose of the NCO Professional Development System (NCOPDS)?
cards.back:
To provide progressive military education and training for NCOs at each rank level.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 5, para 5-2)

cards.front: What is the first level of NCOPDS?
cards.back:
Basic Leader Course (BLC) - required for promotion to SSG (E-6).

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 5, para 5-4)

cards.front: What is the second level of NCOPDS?
cards.back:
Advanced Leader Course (ALC) - required for promotion to SFC (E-7).

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 5, para 5-5)

cards.front: What is the third level of NCOPDS?
cards.back:
Senior Leader Course (SLC) - required for promotion to MSG/1SG (E-8).

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 5, para 5-6)

cards.front: What is the fourth level of NCOPDS?
cards.back:
Master Leader Course (MLC) - required for consideration as SGM/CSM (E-9).

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 5, para 5-7)

cards.front: What is the purpose of the initial counseling session?
cards.back:
To establish expectations, explain duties, and set goals for the rating period.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-10)

cards.front: What information should be included in the NCO Support Form (DA Form 2166-9-1A)?
cards.back:
Duty description, areas of emphasis, and specific goals for the rating period.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 4, para 4-8)

cards.front: What is 'on-the-spot' correction?
cards.back:
Immediate verbal correction of a Soldier's performance or behavior - the first step in maintaining discipline.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 2, para 2-16)

cards.front: What are the seven NCO Common Core Competencies?
cards.back:
Leadership, Communications, Readiness, Training Management, Operations, Program Management, and Adaptive.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-15)

cards.front: What is the purpose of After Action Reviews (AARs)?
cards.back:
To identify what happened, why it happened, and how to improve performance for future operations.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 2, para 2-12)

cards.front: Who conducts an AAR?
cards.back:
The leader responsible for the training event, with input from all participants.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 2, para 2-13)

cards.front: What are the four AAR questions?
cards.back:
What was planned? What actually happened? Why did it happen? What can we do better?

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 2, para 2-14)

cards.front: What is the Sergeant Major of the Army's (SMA) role?
cards.back:
Senior enlisted advisor to the Chief of Staff and principal advisor on enlisted matters.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-18)

cards.front: What are the seven Army Values?
cards.back:
Loyalty, Duty, Respect, Selfless Service, Honor, Integrity, Personal Courage (LDRSHIP).

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-10)

cards.front: What is Loyalty as an Army Value?
cards.back:
Bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution, the Army, your unit, and other Soldiers.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-10)

cards.front: What is Duty as an Army Value?
cards.back:
Fulfill your obligations - carry out all assigned tasks to the fullest of your ability.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-10)

cards.front: What is Respect as an Army Value?
cards.back:
Treat people as they should be treated - with dignity and consideration.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-10)

cards.front: What is Selfless Service as an Army Value?
cards.back:
Put the welfare of the Nation, the Army, and your subordinates before your own.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-10)

cards.front: What is Honor as an Army Value?
cards.back:
Live up to all the Army Values in your actions every day.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-10)

cards.front: What is Integrity as an Army Value?
cards.back:
Do what is right, legally and morally - be honest in all that you do.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-10)

cards.front: What is Personal Courage as an Army Value?
cards.back:
Face fear, danger, or adversity - physical or moral courage to do what is right.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-10)

cards.front: What is the Warrior Ethos?
cards.back:
I will always place the mission first. I will never accept defeat. I will never quit. I will never leave a fallen comrade.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-11)

cards.front: What is the first tenet of the Warrior Ethos?
cards.back:
I will always place the mission first.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-11)

cards.front: What is the second tenet of the Warrior Ethos?
cards.back:
I will never accept defeat.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-11)

cards.front: What is the third tenet of the Warrior Ethos?
cards.back:
I will never quit.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-11)

cards.front: What is the fourth tenet of the Warrior Ethos?
cards.back:
I will never leave a fallen comrade.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-11)

cards.front: What is the NCO's role as a trainer?
cards.back:
Plan, prepare, execute, and assess individual and collective training to standard.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 2, para 2-3)

cards.front: What does 'training to standard' mean?
cards.back:
Ensuring Soldiers can perform tasks correctly every time, meeting all task conditions and standards.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 2, para 2-5)

cards.front: What are the three components of a task?
cards.back:
Conditions (circumstances), Standards (criteria), and Task (what to do).

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 2, para 2-6)

cards.front: What is the difference between training and education?
cards.back:
Training develops skills and knowledge for specific tasks; education develops thinking skills for new situations.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 2, para 2-2)

cards.front: What is a performance-oriented training event?
cards.back:
Training where Soldiers actually perform the task rather than just discussing or watching it.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 2, para 2-7)

cards.front: What is the role of the Company First Sergeant (1SG)?
cards.back:
Senior NCO at company level; advises the commander, executes training, manages personnel.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-16)

cards.front: What is the role of the Command Sergeant Major (CSM)?
cards.back:
Senior NCO at battalion level and above; advises the commander on enlisted matters and standards.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-17)

cards.front: What is mentorship?
cards.back:
Voluntary developmental relationship between experienced and less experienced persons focused on growth.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 5, para 5-10)

cards.front: What is the difference between counseling and mentoring?
cards.back:
Counseling is formal and required; mentoring is informal and voluntary.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 5, para 5-11)

cards.front: What is coaching?
cards.back:
Guiding another through a specific skill or task, providing feedback to improve performance.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 5, para 5-12)

cards.front: What is the nondirective approach to counseling?
cards.back:
Subordinate leads the discussion; leader listens and guides with questions rather than directives.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-16)

cards.front: What is the directive approach to counseling?
cards.back:
Leader controls the discussion, clearly stating expectations and providing specific direction.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-17)

cards.front: What is the combined approach to counseling?
cards.back:
Using both directive and nondirective techniques as appropriate to the situation.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-18)

cards.front: What should a counselor avoid during a counseling session?
cards.back:
Personal attacks, comparisons to others, interrupting, and providing solutions without discussion.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-20)

cards.front: What is performance counseling?
cards.back:
Discussing job performance, strengths, weaknesses, and areas needing improvement.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-6)

cards.front: When is reception and integration counseling conducted?
cards.back:
Within the first two weeks of arrival to a new organization.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-9)

cards.front: What is the purpose of crisis counseling?
cards.back:
To provide immediate assistance for traumatic events; refer to professional resources as needed.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-22)

cards.front: What is referral counseling?
cards.back:
Directing Soldiers to appropriate resources (chaplain, EO, legal, medical) for issues beyond NCO expertise.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-23)

cards.front: What are the three leadership levels?
cards.back:
Direct, Organizational, and Strategic leadership.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-13)

cards.front: What is direct leadership?
cards.back:
Face-to-face leadership at squad, section, platoon, company level.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-13)

cards.front: What is organizational leadership?
cards.back:
Leadership that influences through others at battalion through corps levels.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-13)

cards.front: What is strategic leadership?
cards.back:
Leadership at the highest levels affecting the entire Army and national defense.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-13)

cards.front: What are the three leader competencies?
cards.back:
Lead, Develop, Achieve.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-14)

cards.front: What does the 'Lead' competency include?
cards.back:
Lead others, build trust, extend influence beyond chain of command, and lead by example.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-14)

cards.front: What does the 'Develop' competency include?
cards.back:
Create positive environment, prepare self, develop others, and steward the profession.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-14)

cards.front: What does the 'Achieve' competency include?
cards.back:
Get results through planning, executing, and assessing operations and training.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-14)

cards.front: What are leader attributes?
cards.back:
Character, Presence, and Intellect - the qualities a leader possesses.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-12)

cards.front: What does 'Character' include as a leader attribute?
cards.back:
Army Values, empathy, warrior ethos, and discipline.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-12)

cards.front: What does 'Presence' include as a leader attribute?
cards.back:
Military bearing, professional appearance, fitness, confidence, and resilience.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-12)

cards.front: What does 'Intellect' include as a leader attribute?
cards.back:
Mental agility, judgment, innovation, interpersonal tact, and expertise.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-12)

cards.front: What is the NCO backbone role in the Army?
cards.back:
NCOs are the link between officers and enlisted; they translate orders into action and enforce standards.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-4)

cards.front: What is the principle of 'know your Soldiers'?
cards.back:
Understanding each Soldier's abilities, motivations, limitations, and personal situation.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-5)

cards.front: What does 'taking care of Soldiers' include?
cards.back:
Ensuring their welfare, safety, training, equipment, and professional development.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-7)

cards.front: What is the purpose of the NCO Support Form?
cards.back:
To outline duties, responsibilities, and performance objectives before the rating period begins.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 4, para 4-7)

cards.front: Who completes the NCO Support Form?
cards.back:
The rated NCO with input from the rater, then approved by the rater.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 4, para 4-8)

cards.front: What are the five categories of NCOER performance?
cards.back:
Character, Presence, Intellect, Leadership, and Achieving Results.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 4, para 4-10)

cards.front: What does the rater evaluate on the NCOER?
cards.back:
Day-to-day performance of duties and achievements during the rating period.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 4, para 4-11)

cards.front: What does the senior rater evaluate on the NCOER?
cards.back:
Potential for increased responsibility and promotion compared to peers.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 4, para 4-12)

cards.front: What is the Sergeants Major Academy?
cards.back:
The capstone school for NCO professional development; produces strategic-level NCO leaders.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 5, para 5-8)

cards.front: What is self-development?
cards.back:
Personal responsibility to improve competence through individual study, training, and experience.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 5, para 5-13)

cards.front: What are the three domains of leader development?
cards.back:
Institutional (schools), Operational (units), and Self-development.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 5, para 5-3)

cards.front: What is institutional training?
cards.back:
Formal education at Army schools and centers that provides foundational knowledge.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 5, para 5-3)

cards.front: What is operational training?
cards.back:
Learning through day-to-day unit activities, deployments, and job experience.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 5, para 5-3)

cards.front: What is a training meeting?
cards.back:
Weekly forum to coordinate training requirements and resources at company level.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 2, para 2-9)

cards.front: What is risk assessment in training?
cards.back:
Identifying hazards and implementing controls to minimize risk while maintaining training value.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 2, para 2-10)

cards.front: What is composite risk management?
cards.back:
Five-step process: identify hazards, assess hazards, develop controls, implement controls, supervise.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 2, para 2-11)

cards.front: What is the NCO's role in accountability?
cards.back:
Account for Soldiers, equipment, and sensitive items; report status to leadership.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 2, para 2-17)

cards.front: What is the NCO's role in supply operations?
cards.back:
Maintain property accountability, conduct inventories, and ensure proper storage and maintenance.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 2, para 2-18)

cards.front: What is constructive feedback?
cards.back:
Specific, timely, and actionable information about performance that helps improve future actions.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-19)

cards.front: What is active listening?
cards.back:
Fully concentrating on what is being said, understanding, and responding thoughtfully.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-21)

cards.front: What are the characteristics of effective goals?
cards.back:
Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Realistic, Time-bound (SMART).

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 3, para 3-11)

cards.front: What is the NCO's role in maintaining unit morale?
cards.back:
Set positive example, recognize achievements, address problems, and maintain communication.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-9)

cards.front: What is command climate?
cards.back:
The culture and environment within a unit that affects morale, discipline, and effectiveness.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 2, para 2-19)

cards.front: What is the Army Profession?
cards.back:
A vocation of experts who protect the Constitution, applying ethical expertise in service to the Nation.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 5, para 5-14)

cards.front: What makes the NCO Corps unique?
cards.back:
The only corps in the world trusted to both train and lead enlisted Soldiers.

(Source: TC 7-22.7, Ch 1, para 1-1)
